section.title: Using the &lcm; to Deploy &rhla; Compute Nodes
section.para: The method used for deploying &rhla; compute nodes using Cobbler on the &lcm; will depend on whether your &rhla; nodes are using legacy BIOS or UEFI. We provide steps for both.

section.title: Deploying legacy BIOS &rhla; compute nodes
section.para: The installation process for &rhla; nodes is almost identical to that of &hlinux; nodes as described in . The key differences are:

listitem.para: The standard &rhla; 7.5 iso must be placed in the ardana home directory on the deployer node before you begin the installation procedure. The file must be named rhel7.iso.

You must identify the node(s) on which you want to install &rhla;, by adding the key/value pair distro-id: rhel75-x86_64 to server details in servers.yml. You will also need to update net_interfaces.yml, server_roles.yml, disk_compute.yml, and control_plane.yml. For more information about configuration of the Input Model for &rhla;, see .

section.title: Deploying UEFI &rhla; compute nodes
section.para: Before you attempt to use the &lcm; to install &rhla; on UEFI nodes, you should install any &hlinux; nodes or any &rhla; on legacy BIOS nodes first.
Execute the following steps to re-image one or more nodes after you have run the ready-deployment.yml playbook:

step.para: Prior to beginning these steps, your input model should be configured for your &rhla; nodes, per the instructions at .
Run the following playbook, which will extract the grubx64.efi file which will be needed when imaging your &rhla; UEFI nodes.
Re-image the node(s), ensuring that you only specify your UEFI &rhla; nodes using the nodelist.
Run the wipe_disks.yml playbook to ensure all of your partitions on your nodes are completely wiped prior to continuing with the installation.
The value to use for hostname can be found in ~/scratch/ansible/next/ardana/ansible/hosts.

Make backups of the grub.cfg-* and grubx64.efi files in /srv/tftpboot/grub as they will be overwritten when running the cobbler-deploy playbook on the next step. You will need these files if you need to reimage the nodes in the future.

section.para: Secure Boot is a method used to restrict binaries execution for booting the system. With this option enabled, system BIOS will only allow boot loaders with trusted cryptographic signatures to be executed, thus enable preventing malware from hiding embedded code in the boot chain. Each boot loader launched during the boot process is digitally signed and that signature is validated against a set of trusted certificates embedded in the UEFI BIOS. Secure Boot is completely implemented in the BIOS and does not require special hardware.

listitem.para: Intended to prevent boot-sector malware or kernel code injection.
Extension of the UEFI BIOS architecture.
Optional with the ability to enable or disable it through the BIOS.

section.para: In Boot Options of RBSU, Boot Mode needs to be set to UEFI Mode and UEFI Optimized Boot should be Enabled.
Secure Boot is enabled using System Configuration BIOS/Platform Configuration (RBSU) Server SecuritySecure Boot Configuration Secure Boot Enforcement .
